senses.de: The cost required for something; the money spent on something.
senses.ex: Running a car can be a huge expense.

Tips.title: Financial Priority
Tips.description: Indicates an important financial consideration, often suggesting high cost.
Tips.example: Securing a good education is an expense worth investing in.

Tips.title: Everyday Usage
Tips.description: Commonly refers to typical costs associated with daily life or routines.
Tips.example: Monthly expenses such as rent and utilities are my main financial concern.

Tips.title: Budgeting Term
Tips.description: Often used in the context of managing finances or when budgeting personal earnings.
Tips.example: I track all my expenses in an app to manage my budget better.

senses.de: Something on which money must be spent; necessary costs or losses.
senses.ex: This trip might be a great expense, but it's worth every penny.

Tips.title: Unavoidable Costs
Tips.description: Emphasizes expenses that are essential and can't be avoided.
Tips.example: Medical bills are an unfortunate expense that must be paid.

Tips.title: Sacrifice Implied
Tips.description: Suggests cost in not only money but also time, effort, or other sacrifices.
Tips.example: She completed her project, but not without significant expense of time.

senses.de: In accounting, costs spent by a business in the process of earning revenue.
senses.ex: The capital expense was high this quarter due to new equipment purchases.

Tips.title: Business Context
Tips.description: Specific to costs incurred by businesses and typically used in professional settings.
Tips.example: The company's quarterly report lists travel as a major expense.

Tips.title: Revenue Relationship
Tips.description: In business, expenses are closely tied to profit and loss considerations.
Tips.example: Reducing unnecessary expenses will increase our net revenue.

senses.de: Used to say that someone is insulted or loses respect in order to do something that benefits someone else.
senses.ex: They built a new mall at the expense of the local businesses.

Tips.title: Figurative Cost
Tips.description: Not always monetary; can imply a cost to dignity, reputation, or other intangible factors.
Tips.example: He made a mockery of himself at the expense of getting a laugh.

Tips.title: Social Situations
Tips.description: Used when one person or group benefits or gains humor at another's cost.
Tips.example: Sitcoms often have characters joking at the expense of each other.

Charge.wordDefinition:
Charge refers to the act of billing or asking someone to pay for something. For example, if you go to a restaurant and order food, the restaurant will charge you for the meal.

Charge is also used when talking about electricity, where the amount of electricity used is measured in units of charge.

To summarize, charge refers to the act of billing or asking for payment, while expense refers to the cost of something.

Charge is applicable when selling goods or services, while expense is applicable when talking about the cost of daily life.

Cost.wordDefinition:
Cost refers to the amount of money needed to produce or acquire a good or service. It includes the price of raw materials, labor, and any other necessary expenses.

Cost is usually used in reference to production or manufacturing.

Cost is the price of producing or acquiring something, while expense is the price of using or consuming something.

Disburse.wordDefinition:
Disburse refers to the act of distributing or paying out money, while expense refers to the cost of a particular item or service.

For example, if a company has a budget and needs to pay its employees, the company will disburse funds to the employees' bank accounts.

Disburse relates to the act of distributing money, while expense refers to the cost of goods or services.

Expenditure.wordDefinition:
Expense and expenditure both refer to money spent, but there is a slight difference.

Expenditure refers to the total amount of money that is spent over a period of time, including all expenses. It includes all forms of spending, whether it is on goods or services, and whether it is for personal or business purposes.

For example, if you buy a book for $20, the $20 is the expense. If you keep buying books over the course of a year and spend a total of $500, the $500 is the expenditure.

Expense refers to the cost of a specific item, while expenditure refers to the total amount of money spent over a longer period of time.

Fee.wordDefinition:
Fee refers to a specific charge or price for a particular service or product, such as a membership fee, tuition fee, or consulting fee.

Fees are usually charged as part of a transaction, such as a purchase or service provided.

Expense is a more general term for the costs involved in running something, while fee refers to a specific charge for a particular service or product.

Outlay.wordDefinition:
Expense and outlay are similar but have different nuances.

Outlay usually refers to a one-time or upfront cost, such as buying a new car or investing money in a project.

But if you're talking about the cost of a new computer, you would refer to that as an outlay.

Expense refers to ongoing costs, while outlay refers to one-time or upfront costs.

Overhead.wordDefinition:
Expense refers to any cost incurred in the process of producing or selling a product or service. Overhead specifically refers to the ongoing expenses of running a business that are not directly related to producing or selling a product, such as rent, insurance, utilities, or office supplies.

To simplify, expenses are costs that come with running or selling something, while overhead is a specific set of ongoing costs that are not directly related to production or sales.

Spend.wordDefinition:
Spend refers to the actual act of using one's money to buy things. It involves the use of money to purchase goods or services, whether necessities or luxuries.

Both expense and spend are applicable when talking about money, but expense is the cost of something we regularly pay for, and spend is the money we use to buy things.

For example, rent is an expense, and when we pay rent, we are spending money.

quotes.Text: For most of human history, the main goal of states has been to conquer land and to achieve glory for their rulers, usually at others' expense. Then in recent decades it was all about GDP. It's only in very recent history that rulers have been willing to commit themselves to helping their citizens live happier lives.
quotes.Title: English Educator
quotes.Name: Geoff Mulgan

quotes.Text: I'm very self-deprecating, so I'm not afraid to make jokes at my own expense, and I've just found that makes people a little more comfortable and can open the door for people to feel a little bit more understanding and accepting of where you're coming from.
quotes.Title: American Comedian
quotes.Name: Franchesca Ramsey

quotes.Text: You have to pay attention, like with tours and expenses; you have to factor that all in. You want to play music for the rest of your life, you have to pay attention to all the things. You want to know what's always going on.
quotes.Title: American Musician
quotes.Name: Zakk Wylde

quotes.Text: Most people seem unaware that corporate influence and wealth has taken over public policy, such that government policy now favors the wealthy few at the expense of the people.
quotes.Title: American Politician
quotes.Name: Hank Johnson

quotes.Text: I have to spend my time worrying about poor families at the expense of helping businesses, or vice versa. To me, I really see that's the bridge I need to build.
quotes.Title: Algerian Politician
quotes.Name: Eric Garcetti

quotes.Text: Give a girl an education and introduce her properly into the world, and ten to one but she has the means of settling well, without further expense to anybody.
quotes.Title: British Writer
quotes.Name: Jane Austen

quotes.Text: You can't substitute promise after promise with known violators of prior promises at the expense of protecting ourselves or setting an example.
quotes.Title: American Politician
quotes.Name: Fred Thompson

quotes.Text: The U.S. is just in a class by itself in military expenses. It basically matches the rest of the world, and it's far more advanced.
quotes.Title: American Activist
quotes.Name: Noam Chomsky

quotes.Text: No idea can succeed except at the expense of sacrifice; no one ever escapes without enduring strain from the struggle of life.
quotes.Title: French Philosopher
quotes.Name: Ernest Renan

quotes.Text: Modern life is organised so that you benefit at the expense of the other, and the most extreme example of that is a camp.
quotes.Title: Hungarian Author
quotes.Name: Imre Kertesz
